misconceptions.name: Implements an average-acceleration calculator instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student has written a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers, filtering even numbers, and summing them as required by the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should read v0, v1, and t as doubles and compute (v1 - v0) / t, then print the average acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, identify which of them are even (using a modulus check), accumulate the sum of those even numbers, and print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompts for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers
Program computes (v1 - v0) / t rather than a sum
Output message refers to average acceleration, not sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have reused or copied a solution for a different textbook-style problem about average acceleration instead of implementing the requested sum-of-even-numbers task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and rewrite main so it reads 5 integers, checks each for evenness, adds the even ones to a running total, and prints "Sum of even numbers: " followed by that total.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt, variables, formula, and output text) targets an average acceleration task that is entirely different from the required sum-of-even-numbers problem.

evidence.note: Class name and prompt clearly indicate the student is solving an average-acceleration problem, not the requested sum-of-even-numbers task.
Core computation and output implement average acceleration, not a sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program reads exactly three double values (v0, v1, t) rather than five integers as specified in the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should use nextDouble() three times to read v0, v1, and t for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should use nextInt() (or equivalent) to read exactly five integer inputs from the user, corresponding to the 5 integers in the problem statement.
symptoms: Only three input reads are present
All inputs are doubles, not integers
No mechanism to read 5 separate integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between this assignment and a different problem that asks for three real-valued parameters.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the v0, v1, t inputs with code that reads five integer values (e.g., in a loop or five separate nextInt() calls) and store them in int variables.
related_concepts: Matching input types to problem requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly uses three nextDouble() calls and never uses nextInt() or any construct to obtain five integers.

evidence.note: Three nextDouble() calls for v0, v1, and t instead of reading five integers.

misconceptions.name: No loop or repeated structure to handle multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The solution does not include any loop (for, while, or do-while) to process multiple inputs, contrary to the rubric expectation of using a loop to handle the set of numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is sufficient to read a fixed, small number of values directly without using a loop for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should use a loop to iterate over the required number of inputs (5), reading each value and updating the running sum of even numbers.
symptoms: main contains only straight-line code with three input reads
No for, while, or do-while constructs appear in the program
No repeated processing of five values
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused a non-loop-based template and did not adjust it to meet this problem's requirement to process multiple inputs via a loop.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for or while loop that runs 5 times, reading one integer per iteration, checking if it is even, and adding it to a running total.
related_concepts: Iterative processing of collections of inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly reads a fixed number of values using straight-line code and contains no looping constructs at all.

evidence.note: Entire main method is straight-line code with no loop construct, so inputs are not processed in a loop as required.

misconceptions.name: No conditional check for even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether an input number is even (e.g., using n % 2 == 0) and thus cannot selectively sum only the even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: There is no need to distinguish even numbers; the task is to apply a formula to the three inputs instead.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For each of the 5 input integers, the program should test whether the number is even using a modulus operation (n % 2 == 0) and add it to the sum only if the condition is true.
symptoms: No use of the % operator
No if-statement or boolean condition related to evenness
Sum or selection of even numbers is never computed
misconceptions.root_cause: Because the student implemented a different problem (average acceleration), they did not implement any logic related to identifying even numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an if-statement inside the loop that checks if the current integer is even with n % 2 == 0 and only then add it to the running sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: A full scan of the code shows no conditional logic related to even numbers or use of the modulus operator.

evidence.note: The only computation is a simple arithmetic formula; there is no conditional logic or even-check such as n % 2 == 0.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misalignment with Task Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code written for a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration) instead of the required program (summing 5 even integers). The code reads three doubles and performs an arithmetic calculation instead of incorporating loops, conditional checks, and integer accumulation necessary for the assigned task.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes this code fulfills the requirement to write a program that reads 5 integers and sums the even ones, possibly due to submitting incorrect code from another assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must be structured to specifically solve the 'Sum of Even Numbers' problem, requiring control flow structures (loops and conditionals) and input of five integer data types.
symptoms: Class name does not match task intent (AccelerationCalculator)
Reads only 3 values instead of 5
Reads doubles (nextDouble) instead of integers (nextInt)
No use of loops or conditional logic (if/else)
Performs an arithmetic calculation unrelated to summation ((v1 - v0) / t)
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to write or submit the correct code for the assignment prompt.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem description carefully. Start by implementing a structure to read 5 inputs using a loop, then inside the loop, use an 'if' statement to check for even numbers and add them to a running total.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code bears zero resemblance to the required solution and instead solves a common physics problem, indicating a complete disconnect from the assignment.

evidence.note: The class name suggests a completely different program goal.

evidence.snippet: System.out.print("Enter v0, v1, and t: ");
evidence.note: Prompt asks for variables v0, v1, and t, not 5 general integers.
Reads three doubles, not five integers, and uses Scanner.nextDouble().

evidence.snippet: double average_acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;
evidence.note: Computes acceleration, showing the program is solving an unrelated problem.

misconceptions.name: Completely Wrong Problem Solution
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (acceleration calculator) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). This indicates either a major misunderstanding of the assignment or a submission of code from a different exercise.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this code solves the sum of even numbers problem, or submitted the wrong file entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers and computing the sum of only the even numbers. The submitted code reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) and computes average acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t.
symptoms: Code prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Code reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
Code performs acceleration calculation instead of even number filtering
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No modulo operator or even/odd checking logic
Output is acceleration value, not sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Either the student copied code from a different assignment/exercise without adapting it, or submitted the wrong file for this problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start fresh with this problem. Create a loop that reads 5 integers, use the modulo operator (%) to check if each number is even, and accumulate the sum of only the even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code is objectively solving a different problem entirely. It computes acceleration (physics formula) rather than filtering and summing even numbers. The variable names (v0, v1, t), input prompts, calculations, and output all correspond to an acceleration calculator problem, not the assigned sum of even numbers problem.

evidence.note: Reads 3 double values with physics-related variable names instead of 5 integers for the sum of even numbers problem

evidence.snippet:
double average_acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;
System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + average_acceleration);
evidence.note: Computes and outputs acceleration using physics formula instead of filtering for even numbers and summing them

misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles for velocities instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program is written for an average-acceleration problem: it prompts for v0, v1, and t and reads three double values, instead of reading five integers as required for summing even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: I need to read the starting velocity, final velocity, and time (v0, v1, t) as doubles from the user.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, the program should read exactly five integers from the user (not v0, v1, t) in order to later sum the even ones.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of five integers
Program calls nextDouble() three times rather than reading five values
User cannot provide five separate integers in a single run as required
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have reused or implemented a different textbook-style problem (average acceleration) rather than the specified sum-of-even-numbers task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the v0, v1, and t inputs with logic that reads five integers from the user, e.g., using nextInt() inside a loop.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire input section matches a standard acceleration example and does not reference or accommodate five integers at all.

evidence.note: Code explicitly prompts for three values (v0, v1, t) and reads them as doubles rather than reading five integers.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The program reads a fixed set of three inputs into separate variables without using any loop, so there is no mechanism to process five numbers in a uniform way.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is sufficient to call input.nextDouble() a few times and store the results in separate variables, without using a loop.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To handle five inputs cleanly, the code should use a loop (e.g., a for loop running five times) to read each of the five numbers and process them.
symptoms: No for or while loop appears in main
Each input is read into its own named variable (v0, v1, t) instead of via iteration
Program cannot be easily extended to handle five inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either ignored or did not recognize the need for loops to handle repeated input operations and instead used individual variables.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for loop that iterates five times, reading each integer and updating an accumulator within the loop.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire main method contains no loop constructs; all inputs are read individually into v0, v1, and t.

evidence.note: main contains no for/while loop; inputs are read individually into v0, v1, and t.

misconceptions.name: Missing conditional check for even numbers
misconceptions.description: The code never checks whether a number is even—there is no if statement or modulo operation—and instead performs an unrelated arithmetic formula (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.student_belief: The main arithmetic needed is to compute (v1 - v0) / t for average acceleration, without any conditionals on input values.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, each of the five integers should be tested with a conditional (e.g., if (n % 2 == 0)) to decide whether it should be included in the sum.
symptoms: No use of an if statement in the program
No use of the modulo operator %
Only arithmetic computation performed is (v1 - v0) / t
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a different problem that does not require conditionals and therefore omitted the even-number check entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading each integer, add an if (n % 2 == 0) condition to include only even numbers in the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditionals or modulo operations anywhere in the code; the only calculation corresponds to average acceleration.

        double average_acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;
evidence.note: Instead of using conditionals to check parity, the code performs a single arithmetic expression for acceleration.

misconceptions.name: No accumulator for sum of even numbers and incorrect output message
misconceptions.description: The program computes a single value average_acceleration and prints 'The average acceleration is ...' instead of accumulating the sum of even numbers and printing that sum.
misconceptions.student_belief: The goal is to compute and print the average acceleration based on v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should maintain an integer accumulator that adds up only the even inputs and then print 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by that sum.
symptoms: Variable named average_acceleration is used instead of a sum accumulator
No variable tracks a running total of inputs
Output message refers to 'The average acceleration' rather than 'Sum of even numbers'
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented an acceleration calculator template and did not adapt it to perform summation of even integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an integer variable (e.g., sum = 0) and, inside the loop, add each even integer to this sum, then print 'Sum of even numbers: ' plus the final sum.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to variable design
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only computed value is average_acceleration and the printed message clearly refers to acceleration, not a sum of evens.

evidence.note: Code computes average_acceleration and prints an acceleration-related message instead of summing and printing even numbers.

symptoms: `nextDouble()` is used for input
Variables are declared as `double`

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure variables are declared as `int` and use `nextInt()` to read integers when performing operations like checking for evenness using the modulus operator.
